I.  THE PROPOSAL 
 
1.  I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed 
multitranche financing facility (MFF) to the Republic of Uzbekistan (Uzbekistan) for the Central 
Asia Regional Economic Cooperation (CAREC) Corridor 2 Road Investment Program. The 
design and monitoring framework for the investment program is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  THE INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
 
A.  Rationale 
 
2.  Strategic context. Uzbekistan is a key transit point for Central Asian countries looking 
to trade among themselves, as well as with the rest of Asia and Europe. CAREC has a strategy 
and action plan to develop six transport corridors, which will improve connectivity and cut 
transport costs.1  
 
3.  The  proposed  investment  program  targets  the  Uzbekistan  section  of  CAREC 
Corridor 2—the A380 highway, which connects Uzbekistan to Afghanistan, Kazakhstan, the 
Kyrgyz  Republic,  Tajikistan,  and  Turkmenistan.  Another  highway  investment  now  under 
preparation in Kazakhstan (supported by the Asian Development Bank [ADB]) will connect 
Beyneu (a town on the border with Uzbekistan) with Uzbekistan’s A380 highway and the port of 
Aktau in the Caspian Sea. The two highways, when completed, will provide Uzbekistan and 
other Central Asian countries direct access to the Caspian Sea, and thereafter to South Asia 
and the Black Sea (via road corridors being built in Armenia, Azerbaijan, and Georgia). The 
investment program has strong links to CAREC Corridor 6, which reaches the so-called Ring 
Road in Afghanistan and thereafter the main ports in Pakistan and Iran.    
 
4.  Road sector. Railways used to dominate the freight market, but their market share has 
fallen from 90% in 1997 to 57% in 2009. Increased motorization, a greater number of private 
road hauling companies, and shorter transport hauls of manufactured goods have lifted road 
freight traffic. In 2009, roads accounted for 43% of Uzbekistan’s freight by ton-kilometers (km) 
and 81% of its passengers by passenger-km. This market share is likely to continue to grow, 
especially in the case of general cargo. Railways will retain the main market share in the case of 
bulk and long distance freight. Passenger traffic will grow, but this requires investments in high-
speed train facilities. Some of these are under consideration. 
 
5.  Uzbekistan’s 183,000 km road network comprises 43,000 km of primary roads and 
140,000 km of urban, rural, and other roads. A road sector strategy and road map is in place, 
which prioritizes the 1,200 km A380 highway. The adjoining road in Kazakhstan (between 
Beyneu and Aktau) will add impetus to regional connectivity and increase the viability of the 
investment program road.  
 
6.  A  National  Road  Development  Program  for  2009–20142 has  been  prepared.  It  is 
consistent with the sector strategy and road map and is estimated to cost $2.6 billion—of which 
$1.6 billion is directed at the A380 highway. The investment program will contribute to this 
program. Other investments cover rural and urban roads. The investment involves mainly the 
reconstruction of existing networks, although some green field projects are also envisaged. 
Other  “softer”  infrastructure  investments  are  also  part  of  the  plan,  including  improving 
institutional effectiveness, planning, project management, asset management, maintenance, 
cross-border arrangements and facilities, customs clearance procedures and systems including 
the single window concept, and border point modernization.  
 
                                                 
1   ADB. 2008. CAREC Transport and Trade Facilitation Strategy and Action Plan. Manila. 
2   Resolution of the President of the Republic of Uzbekistan PP-1103 dated 22 April 2009.

2 
7.  Road funding and sustainability. Uzbekistan spends 1% of its gross domestic product 
on the road sector. This remains low by international standards but it has been gradually 
increasing.3 The  general  idea  is  to  bring  funding  to  international  levels  or  higher.  The 
Republican Road Fund (Road Fund) was established under the Ministry of Finance (MOF) for 
this purpose, particularly to deal with capital investment and maintenance for common use 
roads.4 The Road Fund is responsible for up to 25% of all the financing directed at all networks. 
Although the Road Fund has increased its income by about 10% annually in the last 5 years, 
the  investment  needs  are  higher.  This  requires  tapping  alternative  financing  sources,  and 
establishing partnerships with the private sector. Other measures include introducing road user 
charges. Fuel price has been earmarked to finance rural and urban roads development and 
maintenance. 
 
8.  Physical and nonphysical barriers. Uzbekistan has increased road investments and 
introduced sector reforms, but more work is needed on both. With regard to reforms, since 2003 
various actions have been taken in several areas: (i) separating road transport operations from 
road construction, (ii) creating the Road Fund as a quasi-independent body, and (iii) promoting 
competitive  bidding  for  all  road construction  works.  The  government  has  also restructured 
Uzavtoyul (the sole nationwide road agency), converting it to a state joint stock company with 
clear performance and accountability targets.5 A law on automobile road enacted in 2007 now 
allows private sector financing for highway construction. A state-owned road equipment pool 
company created under the ADB loan for CAREC Regional Road Project now services all 
contractors.6  
 
9.  Uzbekistan has a road sector policy framework that supports good governance and 
accountability, improved road sustainability, road safety, and seamless transport logistics as 
well as greater private sector investment and sound road maintenance. Minimizing the cost of 
logistics and improving trade competitiveness requires the dismantling of several tariff and 
nontariff barriers. Improving cross-border facilities will lessen delays.  
 
10.  Relevance and strategic alignment. The proposed investment program fits with ADB’s 
Strategy 2020,7 the country strategy and program 2006–2010 for Uzbekistan,8 and the draft 
country  operations  business  plan  (2010–2011).  The  proposal  is  aligned  to  the  Uzbekistan 
Transport Sector Strategy (2006–2020)9 and road map, as well as the CAREC Transport and 
Trade Facilitation Strategy and Action Plan (footnote 1).  
 
11.  Financing modality. The MFF is the modality of choice for the proposed investment 
program. It follows recommendations from past operations to engage with the government over 
a longer time horizon, and allows ADB to enter into a partnership.10 All the conditions for its use

are in place—a coherent strategy and sector road map, a policy framework, an investment 
program, and a financing plan. Other modalities were considered and discarded. A straight 
policy loan cannot handle reforms as easily as physical investments; a development program 
loan can combine reforms with investments but the investments generally tend to be small and 
over shorter periods; a stand-alone project loan does not ensure continuity or a partnership. A 
sector loan fits better with smaller and more repetitive investments.   
 
B.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The  proposed  investment  program  will  have  an  impact  on  sustainable  economic 
development. The outcome will be better transport connectivity and efficiency, and institutional 
effectiveness.  
 
C.  Outputs 
 
13.  Physical and nonphysical. The outputs will be an approximately 222 km reconstructed 
road section of the A380 highway, and improved planning, project management, logistics, road 
asset management, and community facilities. The investment will be split into three separate 
projects.  
 
14.  Project 1  
 
(i)  Road development. In the first phase, the output will be an approximately 50 km 
reconstructed section of the A380 highway (between Km440 and Km490). This 
section does not involve land acquisition or involuntary resettlement, nor lead to 
significant environmental impacts. The investment will convert the existing road 
section into a four-lane international design road within the existing right-of-way. 
The  cost  includes  civil  works  and  specialized  consulting  services,  including 
experts to help with (a) procurement, environment, and social safeguards; (b) 
construction supervision; and (c) due diligence for subsequent tranches. 
 
(ii)  Road sector sustainability. The following outputs are envisaged: 
(a)  Road  asset  management.  The  output  of  this  program  will  be  an 
expanded road asset management system first introduced under an ADB-
funded transport project (footnote 6). It will finish implementation of the 
system and finance the acquisition of certain facilities such as computers, 
software,  and  automatic  traffic  counting  devices.  It  will  also  fund  a 
specialized training program. It will set up an independent quality control 
system  for  civil  works  and  improve  road  maintenance  contracts.  The 
program will also look into new road financing modalities and the use of 
public–private initiatives.  
(b)  Community development. This part of the program will focus on local 
communities  and  gender  support,  targeting  them  as  beneficiaries. 
Specialized advisory services will help define and execute a number of 
actions.  The  output  will  be  detailed  needs  assessment  of  social  and 
healthcare facilities on villages along project 1 road and a community 
development  and  gender  action  plan  agreed  with  the  Road  Fund 
implemented. 
 
15.  Project 2. The outputs will be an approximately 85 km reconstructed section of the A380 
highway  (between  Km355  and  Km440)  and  procured  road  construction  and  maintenance 
equipment.  
 
16.  Project 3. The outputs will be an approximately 87 km reconstructed road section of the 
A380  highway  (between  Km315  and  Km355,  and  between  Km581  and  Km628)  and

4 
strengthened  logistics  by  improving  cross-border  facilities  and  shortening  the  cross-border 
processing  time.  This  project  will  also  expand  the  community  development  program  and 
institutional capacity.

2.  Financing Plan 
 
19.  To help finance the investment program, the government requested up to $600 million

follow the special operations loan regulations, subject to possible modifications under individual

3.  Filters 
 
21.  ADB  will  consider  financing subsequent  tranches if  the  government  adheres  to  the 
general agreement for the MFF as set forth in the FFA which includes undertakings for the MFF. 
Specific assurances for project 1 should also be complied with by the government. Progress 
towards achieving the outputs and expected outcomes in the DMFs for the investment program 
and project 1 will also be decision-making criteria for financing subsequent tranches under the 
MFF. Project readiness is high. Design work is completed for the project 1 and at an advance 
stage for projects 2 and 3. This will speed up contract awards and the delivery of outputs. 
Advance actions on consultants, bidding document preparation, and retroactive financing are 
features of the proposal. This will facilitate implementation further. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
1.  Management 
 
22.  The Road Fund will be the executing agency. It has already established a program 
management unit (PMU) and appointed a director. The PMU will be structured around teams, 
each  with  a  specific  mandate—technical;  legal;  procurement;  monitoring,  reporting,  and 
evaluations; safeguards, community and gender development, due diligence for subsequent 
tranches, and administration. The Custom Committee will help the Road Fund with work on the 
cross-border facility.  
 
23.  The Road Fund will define a work plan based broadly on the arrangements included in 
the Facility Administration Manual (FAM).12

III.  DUE DILIGENCE 
 
A.  Technical 
 
25.  Due diligence has been carried out for the investment program. This includes assessing 
the investment plan, operational cost structure, and maintenance requirements. It also looked 
into the design features. The road will carry heavy vehicles—from within and outside Uzbekistan. 
The approach is to widen the existing two-lane asphalt concrete road into a four-lane divided 
cement concrete road. Projects 1 and 2 sections will follow the existing right-of-way. Project 3 
sections need a new road alignment.  
 
26.  Road traffic is expected to grow by 10% annually and reach 20,000 passengers car units 
daily by 2039. The reconstructed and expanded network can accommodate this traffic, including 
growing intercity traffic, but this flow of traffic also requires improved road safety measures. Best 
practice standards will be adopted for this purpose. 
 
27.  The civil works will replace the existing asphalt concrete with cement concrete pavement. 
Although the initial investment cost based on cement concrete is higher than that based on 
asphalt concrete, this will be offset later by lower annual maintenance costs. The detailed 
design work for the road section under project 1 has already been completed. ADB evaluated 
this work and found it to be acceptable. Design work for sections under projects 2 and 3 is 
under way. The State Committee for Architecture and Construction verified and approved the 
cost estimates and the design features. The investment program is ready for implementation. 
 
B.  Economic 
 
28.  The investment proposal benefits Uzbekistan as well as its neighbors. Investments of 
this nature have high spillover effect. Other benefits include better, safer, cheaper, and faster 
connectivity. Better connectivity means lower transport costs and greater trade competitiveness, 
which translates into more investments and jobs. The road opens up opportunity but also 
access  to  it.  There  are  substantial  social  benefits,  including  better  access  to  health  and 
education  facilities.  The  main  beneficiaries  include  people  and  local  businesses,  traders, 
neighboring  countries,  and  Uzbekistan  communities  living  along  the  corridor.  The  logistics 
industry will also benefit. The same applies to farmer communities and manufacturers. The link 
to Kazakhstan and the construction of a road from Beyneu to Aktau delivers substantial spillover 
benefits to both countries. This new corridor will give Uzbekistan and Central Asia direct access 
to the Caspian Sea. For a double landlocked country like Uzbekistan, this is a real feat. When 
completed,  this  will  become  a  flagship  corridor  under  CAREC.  The  investment  program’s 
economic rate of return (EIRR) is 16%. 
 
29.  Project 1 investments are also economically viable, with an EIRR of 17%. A sensitivity 
analysis assessed the impact of different benefit and cost scenarios. Under a worst case 
scenario, with traffic 20% lower and construction costs 20% higher (compared to the baseline), 
project 1 still yields an EIRR of 13%. The combined effect of excluding generated traffic and 
ignoring traffic accident savings results in an EIRR of about 15%.  
 
C.  Financial 
 
30.  The due diligence work analyzed the financial management aspects and maintenance 
requirements and capabilities. Current traffic on the road is 1,000 vehicles daily. This is not high 
enough to attract private investors. However, over time, some sections could be spun off to 
private operators, especially around big cities and industrial zones like Navoi. A public–private 
partnership framework will be used to tap into private sector investment. The due diligence work

8 
also revealed sound financial management systems at the Road Fund level. The Road Fund 
has sound systems and procedures, and clear accountability lines.  
 
31.  The Road Fund has resources for road maintenance. It has been receiving an increasing 
budget allocation from the government every year. This will increase in future in line with 
national tax collections. The allocation will be inflation-proof. This will help maintain revenues at 
reasonable levels to help sustain the investments. Generally, countries with road funds spend 
about 0.3% of their income on road maintenance. Uzbekistan falls below this now but intends to 
do better in future. Uzavtoyul will maintain the road. 
 
D.  Governance 
 
32.  A governance assessment was undertaken as part of the due diligence process. This 
focused on the legal framework, regulation, strength of enforcement regimes, capacity of the 
Road Fund, human resources, and the risk of corruption.  
 
33.  The  country’s  performance  on  governance  has  been  lacking  in  some  areas,13 but 
progressing steadily. The legal frameworks for managing public finances have been tightened. 
The Budget System Law and Treasury Law, approved on 17 December 2007, provide additional 
cover and better practices in this area. The public expenditure reform process covering 2007–
2018  includes  measures  to  increase  efficiency,  accountability,  and  transparency.14 These 
reforms  are  tackling  what  are  still  weak  country-level  public  financial  management 
arrangements,  particularly  with  regard  to  budget  execution.  A  major  issue  is  the  public 
procurement process and the issue of price verification for all foreign-funded contracts and 
contract  variations.  The  proposed  investment  will  be  subjected  to  international  competitive 
bidding. This increases oversight and helps mitigate corruption. The verification contributes to 
good  governance,  but  sometimes  creates  project  implementation  delays.  ADB  and  the 
government have agreed actions to reduce these delays through the sharing of databases and 
other information on cost estimates and sources well in advance of loan negotiations.     
 
34.  The  governance  assessment  highlights  a  number  of  risks  areas.  These  and  the 
mitigation  actions  are  summarized  in  the  risk  mitigation  plan  attached  to  the  investment 
program. Specifically, the Road Fund will need to improve further its systems and transparency 
by including in its webpage and the MOF website, information on its performance, the status of 
each contract under the investment program, the specific list of business opportunities, and a 
summary of the bidding process and its guidelines. This would be a major breakthrough on 
public disclosure. It was agreed that an international procurement specialist will be hired to 
assist with the procurement work related to civil works, goods, and services. An independent 
auditor will also be appointed.  
 
35.  ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed 
with MOF and the Road Fund. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the FAM. There is total clarity about the content of the policy, how it needs to 
be applied, and courses of action in case of any infringement.

E.  Poverty and Social 
 
36.  The proposed investment program is not a targeted intervention. It does not specifically 
address poverty reduction through standard direct actions at the level of households, or involve 
specific services that deal with the geographical determinants of poverty. The proposal will not 
exacerbate gender inequities. However, highway construction and the development of long-term 
transit routes increase the risk of sexually transmitted infections. This risk is taken seriously by 
the Government and a mitigation plan has been agreed with ADB. During the execution phase 
of the investment program, these actions will be reflected in the contractors’ contracts. A well-
defined program on targeted awareness and preventive actions will also be prepared.  
 
37.  Communities  living  in  villages  along  a  major  highway  are  often  neglected  when  a 
highway is reconstructed. The Road Fund is aware of the risk and has prepared a community 
and gender action plan. Although it is not a classical mainstreaming gender activity, the action 
plan  has  some  direct  gender  benefits—including  improving  mobility,  job  opportunities,  and 
access to health in the cities/villages along the route. This plan will be executed under projects 1 
and 3 of the investment program. Further needs assessments are required, which will be 
conducted during project 1.  
 
F.  Safeguards 
 
38.  Project 1 does not have any major environmental impacts. In line with ADB’s Safeguard 
Policy Statement,15 project 1 is classified environment category B. The Road Fund has prepared 
an initial environmental examination for project 1 and an environment assessment and review 
framework for the investment program. All this work has been disclosed on ADB’s website. The 
investments will not result in environmental impacts of a regional or international nature. Civil 
works under project 1 do not involve land acquisition, involuntary resettlement, or affect ethnic 
minority groups. Project 1 is classified category C for the purposes of social safeguards. Civil 
works under the subsequent projects may involve land acquisition and involuntary resettlement. 
The Road Fund has prepared a land acquisition and resettlement framework and an ethnic 
minority planning framework. These are also available on ADB’s website. The Road Fund will 
prepare land acquisition and resettlement plans for the future projects, as applicable. The 
program  is  not  expected  to  negatively  affect  people  fitting  ADB’s  definition  of  indigenous 
peoples under ADB’s Safeguard Policy Statement. A safeguard team comprising experts on 
environment and social safeguards will support the PMU. 
 
G.  Risks and Mitigating Measures 
 
39.  Table  6 summarizes  major  risks  and  mitigating  measures.  This  risk  profile  focuses 
mainly on road sustainability. Broader risks include cross-border performance and changed 
macroeconomic conditions. Without efficient border points, trade costs increase and trade flows 
suffer. This ultimately affects the viability of any road corridor. The government has agreed to 
take actions in this area to mitigate such risk. Cross-border point investments are part of the 
package and will affect all borders in all the CAREC countries. ADB intends to support this work 
through a regional program focusing on single windows and customs modernization. Macro 
stability seems assured. Uzbekistan has not been particularly affected by the global financial 
crisis. 
 
 
                                                 
15  ADB. 2009. Safeguard Policy Statement. Manila.

Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
IV.  UNDERTAKINGS AND ASSURANCES  
 
40.  The government has assured ADB that implementation of the investment program shall 
conform to all applicable ADB policies including those concerning anticorruption measures, 
safeguards, gender, procurement, consulting services, and disbursement as described in detail 
in the FAM and loan documents.  
 
41.  The government has given ADB certain undertakings for the investment program, which 
are set forth in the FFA. Specific covenants agreed by the government with respect to individual 
tranches under the MFF are set forth in the loan agreements for the respective tranches. 
 
V.  RECOMMENDATION 
 
42.  I am satisfied that the proposed multitranche financing facility would comply with the 
Articles of Agreement of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and recommend that the Board 
approve the provision of loans under the multitranche financing facility in an aggregate principal 
amount  not  exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $600,000,000  (facility  amount)  to  the  Republic  of 
Uzbekistan for the Central Asia Regional Economic Cooperation Corridor 2 Road Investment 
Program comprising:  
 
(i)  loans in various currencies not exceeding the equivalent of $360,000,000 in 
Special Drawing Rights from the Special Funds resources, with interest to be 
determined in accordance the then applicable policies relating to Special Funds 
resources  and  such  other  terms  and  conditions  as  are  substantially  in 
accordance with those set forth in the framework financing agreement presented 
to the Board, subject to the conditions set forth in paragraph 19 of this report; and 
  
(ii)  loans in an aggregate amount not exceeding the balance of the facility amount 
from  ADB’s  ordinary  capital  resources,  with  interest  to  be  determined  in 
accordance with ADB’s London interbank offered rate (LIBOR)-based lending 
facility, and such other terms and conditions as are substantially in accordance 
with  those  set  forth  in  the  framework  financing  agreement  presented  to  the 
Board.
